items.title: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09405-0 An experimental method is used to assign partial charges based on crystal structure determination through electron diffraction, applicable to any crystalline compound.

items.title: Targeting G1–S-checkpoint-compromised cancers with cyclin A/B RxL inhibitors
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09433-w Dual cyclin A/B RxL inhibitors selectively kill small cell lung cancer cells and other cancer cells with high E2F activity.

items.title: Realization of a doped quantum antiferromagnet in a Rydberg tweezer array
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09377-1 A doped quantum antiferromagnet is obtained by using a Rydberg tweezer array comprising three levels encoding spins and holes to implement a tunable model that allows the study of previously inaccessible parameter regimes.

items.title: Electron flow matching for generative reaction mechanism prediction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09426-9 A new tool based on generative machine learning called FlowER uses flow matching to model reactions as the redistribution of electrons between reactants and products, enabling the enforcement of mass conservation in reaction prediction.

items.title: A fluorescent-protein spin qubit
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09417-w An optically addressable fluorescent-protein spin qubit is realized using enhanced yellow fluorescent protein; the qubit can be coherently controlled at liquid-nitrogen temperatures and the spin detected at room temperature in cells.

items.title: Electrochemical loading enhances deuterium fusion rates in a metal target
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09042-7 A benchtop fusion reactor, called the Thunderbird Reactor, is described, showing that electrochemically loading a metal lattice with deuterium could enhance nuclear fusion rates when that metal is also bombarded by deuterium ions.

items.title: Thymic epithelial cells amplify epigenetic noise to promote immune tolerance
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09424-x The activity of the tumour-suppressor protein p53 is repressed in the thymus to augment fluctuations in background chromatin accessibility as a means of mediating ectopic gene expression and immune tolerance.

items.title: Emerging evidence of abrupt changes in the Antarctic environment
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09349-5 Abrupt changes are developing across Antarctica’s ice, ocean and biological systems; some of these changes are intensifying faster than equivalent Arctic changes, potentially irreversibly, and their interactions are expected to worsen other impacts across the Antarctic environment and global climate system.

items.title: Engineered yeast provides rare but essential pollen sterols for honeybees
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09431-y Genetic engineering of a yeast strain provides rare but essential pollen sterols for honeybee colonies.

items.title: Extremely stripped supernova reveals a silicon and sulfur formation site

items.title: Atomic dynamics of gas-dependent oxide reducibility

items.title: Cancer-induced nerve injury promotes resistance to anti-PD-1 therapy

items.title: A novel bacterial protein family that catalyses nitrous oxide reduction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09401-4 Cultivation of tropical soil microorganisms combined with physiological experiments and bioinformatics analyses identify a family of clade III lactonase-type nitrous oxide reductases with low sequence identity but high 3D structural similarity to known nitrous oxide reductases.

items.title: SLC45A4 is a pain gene encoding a neuronal polyamine transporter
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09326-y The SLC45A4 gene encodes a neuronal polyamine transporter and is linked to pain response in humans and mice.

items.title: A missing enzyme-rescue metabolite as cause of a rare skeletal dysplasia

items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02614-7 Encouraging people to test their local rivers and lakes with simple kits could spark a shift in how we manage water.

items.title: ‘A double-whammy problem’: how plastic dust is altering natural processes

items.title: Visualizing lipid transport in cells

items.title: In-cell structure and variability of pyrenoid Rubisco
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62998-y Rubisco is a central enzyme in the global CO2 fixation during photosynthesis. items.title: Current challenges and future directions for brain age prediction in children and adolescents
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63222-7 This Perspective outlines how brain-age prediction models are increasingly applied to child and adolescent populations and examines the specific challenges this entails. items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63123-9 Developing strong, thermally resistant adhesives for load-bearing applications remains challenging. items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02590-y An infant with an inherited life-threatening metabolic condition has responded to a tailored therapy that uses the gene-editing tool CRISPR to correct a specific mutation.

items.title: Battery prices are falling, so why are electric cars still so expensive?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02619-2 Policies incentivizing electrified transport don’t seem to be working. Here’s what we need to do.

items.title: Small, affordable undergraduate research programmes changed my career and strengthen US science. Why cut them?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02242-1 Like so much else, this small scientific programme is on the Trump administration’s hit list. This will hurt the United States, says Dan Seaton.

items.title: Exercise improves survival of some people with colon cancer, clinical trial shows
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02591-x Most studies on how exercise affects the survival of people with cancer have been observational. A clinical trial provides compelling evidence of the benefits of physical activity.

items.title: People are having fewer babies: Is it really the end of the world?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02615-6 Steep population declines in most countries are expected to have negative impacts over the next several generations, but adaptation is possible.

items.title: Why strong mentorship was essential for my career success in science
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02634-3 JoAnn Trejo has turned mentoring into an evidence-based science, driven by her own exposure to inspiring mentors.

items.title: Immunotherapy using CAR T cells shows promising long-term outcomes for people with the blood cancer myeloma
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02592-w A clinical trial reports data from one of the first groups of people with the blood cancer myeloma to receive a type of immunotherapy called CAR T cells.

items.title: How changes in behaviour can save lives in disasters
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02613-8 Enabling people to take more personal responsibility for their safety can reduce the risks posed by earthquakes and floods.

items.title: Magnon-polaritons dance around exceptional points
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02999-2 Coherent control of magnon excitations is crucial for their potential device application. The integration of the exceptional point in a magnon-photon hybrid system is shown to offer fast, coherent and topologically robust control of magnon-polariton states.

items.title: Coherent control of magnon–polaritons using an exceptional point
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02998-3 Deterministic control of the gain–loss balance in non-Hermitian systems remains challenging. A magnonic hybrid platform is now shown to enable this and, hence, coherently control excitations by leveraging an exceptional point.

items.title: Image-guided treatment of mouse tumours with radioactive ion beams
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02993-8 Particle therapy is subject to uncertainties in the range of the beam. In this study, tumours in the necks of mice were treated with radioactive ion beams, which enabled real-time verification of the beam range.

items.title: Orchestrated growth factor release for muscle restoration
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02330-7 Implantable bioconstructs with sequential release of growth factors promote enhanced myofibre formation, angiogenesis and innervation in a mouse model of volumetric muscle loss.

items.title: Signatures of magnetism in zigzag graphene nanoribbons embedded in a hexagonal boron nitride lattice
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02317-4 Nitrogen-vacancy-centre microscopy and anisotropic magnetoresistance measurements reveal the evidence of magnetism in zigzag graphene nanoribbons embedded in hexagonal boron nitride.

items.title: An energy metabolism-engaged nanomedicine maintains mitochondrial homeostasis to alleviate cellular ageing
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-01972-7 Through binding mitochondrial ATP synthase, engineered nanomedicines rejuvenate aged bone stem cells and restore osteogenesis, reversing osteoporosis in mice and offering a potential senolytic therapy for skeletal ageing.
